definitions.definition: ( transitive , ergative ) To shut with sudden force so as to produce a shock and noise.
( transitive , ergative ) To put in or on a particular place with force and loud noise. (Often followed by a preposition such as down , against or into .)
examples: Don't slam that trunk down on the pavement!

definitions.definition: ( ambitransitive ) To strike forcefully with some implement.
( intransitive ) To strike against suddenly and heavily.
examples: The boat slammed into the bank and we were almost thrown into the river.

definitions.definition: ( transitive , slang ) To strike and take the life of or at least incapacitate for some time.
( transitive , sports slang ) To defeat or overcome in a match .
( transitive , colloquial , originally US ) To speak badly of; to criticize forcefully.
examples: Don't ever slam me in front of the boss like that again!
Union leaders slammed the new proposals.
Critics slammed the new film, calling it violent and meaningless.

definitions.definition: To compete in a poetry slam .
( basketball ) To dunk forcefully, to slam dunk .
( transitive , telecommunications ) To move a customer from one service provider to another without their consent .
( transitive ) To drink off , to drink quickly.
( ambitransitive , drugs , slang ) To inject intravenously ; shoot up .
( transitive , sex , slang , vulgar ) To perform coitus upon forcefully; to rail .
( informal , US ) To occupy and busy with a high workload.

definitions.definition: To defeat (opponents at cards) by winning all the tricks of a deal or a hand .

main_definition: ( transitive , card games ) To defeat (opponents at cards) by winning all the tricks of a deal or a hand .
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive , bridge ) To make a slam bid .
